1. difference-between-explicit-and-impli.title: Difference between explicit and implicit types in typescript ?
1. difference-between-explicit-and-impli.content:
Explicit types are used when you know the type of the variable. Implicit types are used when you don't know the type of the variable.

**Explicit types**

```typescript
let name: string = "John"
let age: number = 30
let isMarried: boolean = false
```

**Implicit types**

```typescript
let name = 'John'
let age = 30

let isMarried = false

```

11. what-is-build-time-error.title: What is build time error?
11. what-is-build-time-error.content: Errors that occur when you violate the rules of writing syntax are known as build-Time errors. This compiler error indicates something that must be fixed before the code can be compiled. All these errors are detected by the compiler and thus are known as build-time or compile-time errors.

2. do-we-need-to-compile-typescript-file.title: Do we need to compile TypeScript files and why?
2. do-we-need-to-compile-typescript-file.content: Yes we do. Typescript is just a language Extension browsers can't interpret it. Converting from TypeScript to JavaScript is called compiling. Compiling doesn't mean binary code is created in this case. For this kind of translation, also the term transpilation is used instead of compilation.

24. What are Modules in Typescript?.title: What are Modules in Typescript?
24. What are Modules in Typescript?.content:
In Typescript, we can use modules to organize our code. A module is a file that contains a group of related code. We can make some of them public to view from outside the module, and some of them private to hide from outside the module. To make a module public, we use the export keyword.

### Example

**index.ts**

```typescript
export class Person {
	name: string = ''
	constructor(public name: string) {
		this.name = name
	}
}
```

**App.ts**

```typescript
import { Person } from './index'

const person = new Person('John Doe')

console.log(person.name)
```

24. Why do we need to compile TypeScript.title: Why do we need to compile TypeScript?
24. Why do we need to compile TypeScript.content: Browser can only understand JavaScript. So we need to compile Typescript to JavaScript. If we try to run Typescript code directly, it will not work. Because browsers don't understand it.
24. Why do we need to compile TypeScript.section: 24. Why do we need to compile TypeScript?

26. What is the difference between .ts a.title: What is the difference between .ts and .tsx ?
26. What is the difference between .ts a.content:
`.ts` files contains only pure TypeScript
`.tsx` have included JSX also.

On another point of view, you can copy everything from a .ts file and paste on .tsx file, and you don't need to modify anything. But if you're copying from a .tsx file you need to refactor it by removing the JSX elements.
26. What is the difference between .ts a.section: 26. What is the difference between .ts and .tsx

29. What does TypeScript map file do?.title: What does TypeScript map file do?
29. What does TypeScript map file do?.content: `.map` files are source map files that let tools map between the emitted JavaScript code and the TypeScript source files that created it. Many debuggers (e.g. Visual Studio or Chrome's dev tools) can consume these files so you can debug the TypeScript file instead of the JavaScript file.
29. What does TypeScript map file do?.section: 29. What does TypeScript map file do?

31. What are conditional types in TypeSc.title: What are conditional types in TypeScript?
31. What are conditional types in TypeSc.content: Taking a decision makes function useful for a different type of input. Conditional types, as the name suggests, define the types of value on the basis of conditions. Now, Conditional types seem like a conditional statement, although, it is same in the way that the conditional statement is used to choose the flow of code based on certain conditions and conditional  types used for choosing different types for values.
31. What are conditional types in TypeSc.section: 31. What are conditional types in TypeScript?

32. How do you make an array read-only?.title: How do you make an array read-only?
32. How do you make an array read-only?.content:
Using the typescript utility. The `ReadonlyArray<T>` type is a read-only array type. It is a subtype of the `Array<T>` type. This type is useful when you want to ensure that the array is read-only.

**Example**

```typescript
const arr: ReadonlyArray<number> = [1, 2, 3];
arr[0] = 4; // Error!
arr.push(4); // Error!
arr.length = 0; // Error!
arr.splice(0, 1); // Error!
```
32. How do you make an array read-only?.section: 32. How do you make an array read-only?

38. What are decorators in TypeScript?.title: What are decorators in TypeScript?
38. What are decorators in TypeScript?.content: A Decorator is a special kind of declaration that can be attached to a class declaration, method, accessor, property, or parameter. Decorators use the form @expression , where expression must evaluate to a function that will be called at runtime with information about the decorated declaration.

39. Should I use type or interface TypeS.title: Should I use type or interface TypeScript?
39. Should I use type or interface TypeS.content: nterfaces are most recommended for defining new objects or methods or properties of an object where it will receive a specific component. Hence interface works better when using objects and method objects. Therefore it is our choice to choose between types or interface according to the program needs.
39. Should I use type or interface TypeS.section: 39. Should I use type or interface TypeScript?

4. list-the-built-in-types-in-typescript.title: List the built-in types in Typescript ?
4. list-the-built-in-types-in-typescript.content:
Number type: it is used to represent number type values and represents double precision floating point values.

```typescript
var variable_name: number;
```

**String type:** it represents a sequence of characters stored as Unicode UTF-16 code. It is the same as JavaScript primitive type.

```typescript
var variable_name: string;
```

**Boolean type:** in Typescript, it is used to represent a logical value. When we use the Boolean type, we get output only in true or false. It is also the same as JavaScript primitive type.

```typescript
variable_name
```

**Null type:** it represents a null literal and it is not possible to directly reference the null type value itself.

```typescript
var variable_name:number = null;

```

**Undefined type:** it is the type of undefined literal. This type of built-in type is the sub-type of all the types.

```typescript
var variable_name:number = undefined;

```

5. what-are-the-benefits-of-typescript.title: What are the benefits of TypeScript?
5. what-are-the-benefits-of-typescript.content:
The main benefit of TypeScript is that it can highlight unexpected behavior in your code, lowering the chance of bugs.

- It helps in code structuring.
- Use class based object oriented programming.
- Impose coding guidelines.
- Offers type checking.
- Compile time error checking.
- Intellisense

8. what-is-typescript.title: What is Typescript?
8. what-is-typescript.content: TypeScript is a free and open-source programming language developed and maintained by Microsoft. It is a strict syntactical superset of JavaScript, and adds optional static typing and class-based object-oriented programming to the language.

9. what-is-unions-in-typescript.title: What is Unions in typescript?
9. what-is-unions-in-typescript.content:
Unions are a way to combine multiple types into a single type.

**Variable Example**

```typescript
let isDone: boolean | number = false
```

**Function Example**

```typescript
function add(x: number, y: number): number | boolean {
 return x + y
}
```
